Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Toward a unified model for ferrihydrite nanoparticles behavior in the environment: a multipronged investigation of surface structure and reactivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences program in the Division of Chemistry at the National Science Foundation, Professors Nadine Kabengi, James D Kubicki and Michael L Machesky all at Georgia State University and Professor Maria Chrysochoou at the University of Connecticut (UCONN) are exploring the modeling of interfacial chemical reactions in order to determine the fate and transport of contaminants in the environment. The project will support two graduate students who will experience highly interdisciplinary collaborative experimental and theoretical training at the respective institutions. It will also create several opportunities for undergraduate student involvement in research with mentors who are not only excellent role models for women and underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines, but also consistently strive to increase participation of these groups in STEM research. The project's impact is enhanced by the inclusion of its intellectual approaches in many courses taught by faculty in the Chemistry, Geoscience, and Environmental Engineering departments at the institutions, which exposes a larger number of students to important environmental geochemical concepts and techniques. Furthermore, they will integrate project concepts into their established K-12 outreach activities and web-based modules dissemination in addition to their presentations at scientific meetings. Through these activities, an effective integration of research collaborations will develop across several geochemical disciplines.

The collaborative research groups are investigating the interplay between the bulk structure, surface properties, and environmental reactivity of ferrihydrite, a ubiquitous complex iron oxide. To meet this challenge, the groups are integrating experimental thermodynamics obtained through flow adsorption microcalorimetry with computational chemistry, spectroscopy, and surface complexation modeling. This framework utilizes, for the first time, a recently proposed ferrihydrite structure to model its surface reactivity. The ultimate goal of the surface studies is to develop a predictive-mechanistic understanding of the interplay between a surface structure and its environmental reactivity, which will demonstrate the strength and applicability of incorporating directly measured thermodynamics data into environmental studies of mineral-solution interfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Contamination of soil and groundwater resources with heavy metals is widespread due to poor past management practices of industrial waste and wastewater. To effectively predict and manage groundwater with heavy metals, we rely on models that incorporate both the description of water flow, and the chemical reactions that take place between contaminants dissolved in water and soil particles. Iron oxides are important soil constituents that have a high ability to retain heavy metals and metalloids, so that an accurate mathematical description of both the properties of the iron oxides and their interaction with contaminants.  The focus of this project was to investigate and model the surface properties of one of the most reactive types of iron oxides in the environment, the mineral ferrihydrite.

This project was a collaboration between four different teams: an environmental engineer and geochemist (Dr. Chrysochoou, University of Connecticut), a soil scientist (Dr. Kabengi, Georgia State University), a computational chemist (Dr. Kubicki, University of Texas at El Paso) and an environmental modeler (Dr. Machesky, Illinois State Water Survey). This group effort investigated the complex interplay between the bulk structure, surface properties, and environmental reactivity of ferrihydrite. To meet this challenge, the groups integrated several different techniques: experimental flow adsorption micro-calorimetry, spectroscopy, traditional batch adsorption studies, computational chemistry, and surface complexation modeling. The integration of the four techniques improved the robustness of the insights gained, eliminating contradictory results and reducing the assumptions needed to develop surface complexation model. The use of experimental thermodynamics was particularly useful in highlighting limitations of the computational approach, a driver for future improvements in this field.

 

An international collaboration supplement for the project was also obtained to form a collaboration with Dr. Mario Villalobos at the Universidad Autonoma de Mexico, an expert in iron oxide chemistry. Dr. Villalobos worked with the UCONN group to build an experimental system to study the adsorption of carbon dioxide on iron oxides. Understand the influence of carbon dioxide, a compound that is present in every environmental system, is key to accurate modeling efforts.

 

A key outcome of the research is an improved algorithm to conduct multi-parameter optimization of surface complexation models. This algorithm can be adopted for any modeling formalism of the several existing ones and for any sorbent-sorbate system, extending the applicability of the tool to any interfacial system beyond the ones studied in the project. The robustness of the algorithm was demonstrated in a model system involving several iron oxides, and helped develop a framework to model several types of iron oxides as a single surface.

Broader Impact

During the four years of the project, four graduate students (3 Ph.D., 1 MS) and eight undergraduate students have taken part in the training and research activities described above. The students had the opportunity to interact with an interdisciplinary, diverse team of experts and students across several institutions and receive training in multiple experimental and modeling techniques. Collectively, the team gave 25 presentations in local meetings, national and international conferences, providing both undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity to present their research to scientific audiences. Seven journal papers, one dissertation and one referred conference paper also resulted from the project.

The project?s impact was enhanced by the inclusion of its intellectual approaches in several courses taught by faculty in the Chemistry, Geoscience, and Environmental Engineering departments at the four institutions, which exposed a larger number of students to important environmental geochemical concepts and techniques. Finally, the UCONN graduate students made presentations to high school and elemental school students on soil and water quality, in an effort to promote STEM and environmental literacy in K-12.
